title: "Oh boy Ekko lore, I'll finally find out how he's connected to the other champions....within the..."
body:
Ooh, a mysterious villain, could this guy be an enemy in disguise? The madman who created the Noxian monster he fought in the video? The creator, perhaps, of other noxian monsters including Urgot?

maybe I'll finally find out if Ekko rolled with Vi and Jinx! Maybe we'll find out if Ekko has gained eternal youth from his invention, and the little kid with the glasses is Viktor? 

Or maybe not. Maybe he's just some complete and utter random schmoe who is, ONCE AGAIN, totally unconnected to anyone or anything besides his artistic aesthetic tying him to wherever he's supposed to be from. 

Grimy = Zaun, Evil = Noxus, Good = Demacia, Asian = Ionia, Steampunk = Piltover, Zombie = Shadow Isles, Icy = Freljord, Purple = Void. We get it. They're from places. That does not mean you are "creating a world" it just means you've sorted your unconnected one dimensional meaningless action figures into boxes. 

The worst part is, Narrative is probably gonna clap their hands and say "Immersion achieved, now we don't have to do shit until the next champion release. Boy oh boy are we doing such a good job. Thanks again for the minor assist, Art Team".

replies.body:
First, thanks for all the kind words and thoughtful discussion. 

This is my opinion: Ekko is a character whose personality really excited us. With the comic and the trailer we wanted to tell stories about Ekko to introduce him to our world, to see what he's made of, to see what drives him, motivates him, breaks him. The story for the comic actually came out early in the champion's development, and did have a few teases to other champs. Rest assured, there was NOTHING substantial in these teases, just words to describe other characters. It was like Ekko offhandedly mentioning "the Machinist". It was an allusion to Viktor. Ultimately, those teases distracted from the story. As any writer worth their salt will say: if it distracts from the story, it's the first thing to get cut. 

Having other LoL characters fully present in these tales would shift the emphasis away from Ekko to the interactions with other champions.

> 
> Having other LoL characters fully present in these tales would shift the emphasis away from Ekko to the interactions with other champions.

But _not_ adding other champions also backfires - it isolates him. You can't keep him apart from other champions for long, or he'll fall into the same place as Ahri, Sona, Rengar, Nidalee. People with either no allegiances or no reason to get into world affairs. Yeah, Ekko could just be some kid from Zaun. But one of the big, cool things about lore was how each Champion meant something to the overall story, how each had something. Minor, like Sivir breaking  a car and going to trial, to overarching importance, such as Kayle being the inquisitor of sorts for the Institute of War...to Garen and Katarina breaking up a bar fight during the Kalamanda catastrophe, LeBlanc posing as Jarvan iV...

That was one of the drives, yaknow? How each champion ultimately meant something in the world, and actually could add to the story. 

So, don't let Ekko fall into the same place as Ahri and Co above. Because, if you do, and keep everything focused on him...if you keep stories focused on one champion only, you'll have 200 short stories about people that mean nothing to one another, unless their in the same citystate/army/fighting each other because of the former.



So, I'll leave off with a question - how do you propose to avoid this? Kayle and Ahri are my favorite champions besides Lux, yet Kayle is from another world so far and Ahri is just....there. So...what ideas have you thought of already, to tie all your champions together so none are just sitting in a swamp/forest/mountain/ doing nothing while the world ends?

It _doesn't_ exist anymore. They retconned the League along with its Summoners.
Well, they said they were going to. As far as you can tell in-game, it still exists (go look at, I dunno, Fiddlesticks' lore).

Riot said they were planning on updating the lore of champions who are tied to the League of Legends.  This was announced back when the Ret-con was released.  Why it hasn't been done yet is a mystery to everyone, and it leaves players questioning just what exactly the lore team is doing.  

I've come to accept the Ret-con.  When it first was announced I hated it.  I loved that I was a Summoner and that even though I wasn't very good I was still important to the game's story.  It wasn't like in RPGs where you were this incredibly powerful hero who was capable of taking on monsters and demons and sometimes even gods alone.  As a Summoner I was important, but I was just a cog in the machine of the Institute of War, and it was a pretty neat hook.  I don't think I'd have kept playing this game if it hadn't been for that.  But Riot has stood firm and will not reverse their decision to keep the IoW and the Summoners, and there is nothing we can do.  I realise this now.  I may not like it, but fighting the Lore team is not worth the effort I'd put in and it will amount to nothing in the end.  

But the fact that nothing has been done to rectify the lore of champions like Fiddlesticks and Jax and Orianna and Brand and Cho'Gath (along with many others) makes me a bit annoyed.  They all have a direct link to an organisation which no longer exists, leaving them in a weird limbo-state when it comes to lore.  I've played DotA 2 and Heroes of the Storm (really like it too, Anub'arak's so fun) despite the fact that both games have a very loosely defined lore.  In HotS's tutorial your hero asks something like 'But why are we all doing this?  Why are we here fighting random enemies to destroy their Core?'  The answer is 'Don't question it.'  That's it.  That's the lore.  You're playing the game to have fun.  This is mostly possible because all the heroes have backstories tied to other games.  Like Nintendo's done  in SSB, Blizzard's games let you know who Arthas is, who Raynor is, what Tyrael is, etc.  Their stories are concrete and not likely to change.  In League of Legends, we don't know anymore.  We all saw that the IoW was having less and less to do with new champions, but I don't think many people saw it ever being removed from the game entirely, at least not without something major to take its place.  

And as of right now, its removal was pretty useless.  Sure, we'd have to question why champions like Jinx, Rek'Sai, Bard, and Lissandra would ever fight under the control of a Summoner regardless of what they were offered, but now we have even less.  Now we just know little snippets of these champions' pasts, with very little beyond a particular incident revealed at their release.  While that snippet is interesting and usually very well-done (for example, the art in the Chronobreak comic was amazing) we need more to fully understand a champion.  "But it's supposed to be mysterious!" only goes so far, especially since every champion released in the past year has had some 'mystery' surrounding them.  Rather than questioning why Summoners are controlling champions, we're left wondering why they're even fighting at all.  Why is Bard, essentially a god-like celestial being, helping Rek'Sai fight Azir and Braum?  

The 'Because reasons." excuse works in Heroes of the Storm because HotS has always been about that.  It's a silly concept, but with interesting execution and good gameplay.  League of Legends doesn't have that excuse.  It had a fully-established universe, and even though it was never the best writing, it's a lot better than what we've seen recently.  Don't misunderstand me, I like things like Chronobreak and Mountain and Trials of the Poro, but considering that's where the champions' stories seem to end, they end up just being disappointing.  Since release, we've learned nothing new about Vel'Koz, Gnar, Yasuo, Braum, etc.  Their lore, while interesting at the time, has stagnated and we're left asking where the Lore Team is and what they're doing.  

This ended up being a lot longer and more of a rant than I intended.  
**TL;DR**:  Mysterious pasts are good but not everyone needs one, champions do not exist in a vacuum, and their stories shouldn't just stop once the hype for their release is done.

This is bad writing at its finest, sorry :/ Champions should not be in their own "Spheres"  - they need to have conflict with one another, or they end up lacking character, motivation and personality. Look at Kalista, for example, she has the personality of a rock.

Kalista isn't the life and soul of the party, but there's a lot going on with her. We have to do a better job of showing it to you.

I disagree that a character is one-dimensional because he or she isn't initially involved with a large variety of other Champions. Each character has to have a strong, cohesive thematic through-line and personality for them to make their interactions with other Champions exciting. If Champions were not interesting without others, none of them would be interesting.

But, Kalista/Ekko ARE one-dimensional. Adding tragedy to a story does not create depth. I am a writer by trade, what you are doing with these one off stories do not grow a character. Azir was done okay. Even the shot/easy Kha'zix told a story. A simple one, but at least one with definitive goals/desires. 

After reading the Ekko comic, this is what we know:

1. His friend died after trying to steal from a guy.
2. He couldn't save him.
3. Ekko sent him out to get food just to get rid of him, so he has guilt.

Nothing of this tells us who Ekko is. Is he an inventor? A thief who stole the Z-drive? There is NOTHING, that makes Ekko more than just a character. We don't see what makes him special, someone who would be on the Rift. And there in is the flaws.

This sounds like the most politically correct way to say that you and your company are not trying to sell a story but rather a fighting game. 

I find it odd however that I can go boot up a super nintendo mortal kombat game and read more background about a "character" than most of the champions in league. Withholding the 20 year difference between the games. 

Fighting games thrive on characters uniquely interacting with the other characters, It is ignorant to believe you will keep producing champions that are unique but never tie in their strengths or weaknesses to other champions in the game.

It reminds me of being super young and playing an imaginary game of super heros with your friends. After coming up with your own story and super powers 2 things always ruined it.

1. Some kid always had to have "all" the powers. This is basically what you do 80% of the time you release a champion. You invent a new better version of a champion and soon several champions that were similar to it are now outdated and useless. 

2. No one wanted others to be involved in their storyline. That is what you are doing and defending on the forums now. 

There is one storyline in this game. "Champions" (people) from around runeterra (the world) fight for passionate reasons. If you want it to be in league so that the ongoings of the world of runeterra outside of micro statements on patchnotes and the pathetic storytelling you call champions lore is non-existent then tell your community that and quit leading them in a sloppy circle of misinformation. But know that there are in fact people who are not pro's at this game, who are not be the best driven but actually enjoy part of the **background** to this chaos, and that those people you will lose if your intent is to leave this part of your game stagnant.

As stupid as the plot to Mortal Kombat is, at least it performs the basic function of a video game plot: it explains what's going on in the game, why these characters are fighting, and what might be at stake. I'm not saying Mortal Kombat does that in a particularly interesting way, but it does get the job done.


# Paint the freaking fence
A video game with no story is like an unpainted wooden fence. It's still a perfectly decent fence. It might not be very exciting, but it will keep the neighbor's dog out of the yard. It looks kind of shabby. It seems to be missing something.

http://momcomplex.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/fence.jpg
If you hire someone to paint a fence, and someone slaps a coat of white paint on it with some mediocre brushwork, at least they painted the fence. It looks a bit nicer. It has something to keep the rain from warping it. This is the Mortal Kombat or Street Fighter approach. There's some kind of explanation for what's going on. It satisfies that part of our minds that instinctively looks for a story to go with what's happening. Humans love stories. We anthropomorphize just about everything. When we see a struggle, we want to know what the story is behind the struggle. The "crazy dictator starts a tournament to see who is the most badass fighter ever" story is a white picket fence: gets the job done, avoids the lack of a story from detracting from the game, the way an unpainted fence warps in rainy weather. 

http://fencepictures.org/large/216/Wood-Picket-Fence-Pictures-5.jpg 
Riot's current approach is like taking out a canvas and painting a landscape, then putting it next to the unpainted fence, and telling the person who hired you, "Yeah, I know it's not painted, but just look at the painting here, and try to think about the painting when you look at the fence." Mortal Kombat at least slaps a coat of white paint on the fence. If someone asks, "Wait, why is this dude punching this other dude?", you can say, "oh, uh, it's like a tournament or something," and assuage that awkwardness.

http://images.stockfreeimages.com/1565/sfi/free_15651829.jpg http://i.imgur.com/OcIBw4I.jpg
Better still would be to find a way to paint the fence and use its awkward shape as an artistic constraint to produce something interesting or clever, maybe having each stake as one panel of a series of images, or painting them to look like pencils, or whatever. But I'll take the workmanlike "it's now a painted white fence" option over the "I didn't paint the fence, I painted this other thing" option anyday.

It's all the more tragic because, as derpy as it was, I think the pre-retcon lore actually did a good job of working with the constraints of the game to produce something kind of clever: a fantasy UN of sorts, swapping out international tribunals for a form of trial by combat, with the players immersed into the universe as mages, diplomats, and adventurers who support Champions while trying to navigate a quite treacherous international arena.

To continue the analogy, rather than getting all upset because the fence isn't a traditional canvas, and spurning the central task at hand to do something else, the original lore accepted the quirks of the task and used it as inspiration to create something that was actually quite novel.

What is wrong with giving us more story and less "easter eggs" and teasers?  Is the disconnect so bad within Riot that you guys can't see this is what we, your lore fans, are after?  God damn, this is infuriating.

> [{quoted}](name=Sneak Dog,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=kGhinZuR,comment-id=00040000000000040000,timestamp=2015-05-22T00:26:56.826+0000)
>
> I agree, the timing is entirely messed up. These should be interactions that happen at the start of the game, when at the summoning platform. You can have a bit of banter between some champions, perhaps rivalry.

It's worse than that.  In order to hear these lines, you have to:

1.  Face off against one of a handful of specific opponents.
2.  Get close enough to taunt them.
3.  Type "/t" or hit Ctrl+2.
4.  Hope that they're not hitting you for damage, they're not counter-taunting or laughing at you or hope that your teammates aren't pinging the map like a hummingbird... with ADHD... on crack.

Then, and only then, do you get one of the special taunts that answers a tiny portion of his lore questions.

Absolutely impractical for a casual lore fan, if you ask me.

Eh, or you can just... y'know... bind taunt to any other key on the keyboard? Notably, 'z,' 'x,' and 'c' don't have any impact on the game and are right under standard finger placement. Perfect for joke, taunt, and laugh. Dance goes on 'h,' as it's not worth putting in prime real estate.

Also if you just hit the button it'll continue the VO if you cancel the rest of the animation (Very common knowledge, but it's best to be explicit).

There is no real difference between Ctrl+2 and changing the button to Z.  That's missing the point, which is that there are a number of distractions in game that make putting important pieces of lore in the game an annoyance.  In the FEW games where you face the right champions for the special lines, you have to hope that you'll not sacrifice anything by doing the taunt, and it won't get interrupted by pings or combat sounds or anything else.  Not only that, but you would have to use taunt multiple times, and against EVERY champion, to make sure you don't miss something.  Ekko and Zilean might be obvious, but Ekko and Viktor wouldn't be.  Without that, you are just looking up shit on a wiki, and that loses something.

If they were SO INTENT on disconnecting the game from the lore that they had to get rid of the central theme of the game, why are they still putting important bits of lore INSIDE the game only?

With respect, if the game is separate from the story, it's hard to treat those character interactions as more than just Easter eggs. That's a part of why we want interactions in lore. As flawed as the Shurima event was it succeeded in that.

A thousand times this: if the game doesn't represent anything real, then anything happening on the Fields of Justice isn't a true interaction between these characters and so doesn't represent, well, anything. It's so much better to have the champions actually interacting with one another in a setting in which they can all congregate.

My question is, how will you take him further? In reference to my other post, which I hope you see, you killed off pretty much the one link so far that could connect Ekko elsewhere, and easily formulate a storypath where he can leave Zaun.

Again: This story's done. How will you further take Ekko (and many other champions) out of their places (Like Ahri, or Rengar) and bring them into the overarching scheme of things? With no IoW to link them and make all sorts of stories and shenanigans, I've curious to how your next story will further Ekko's, and bring him into contact with even more champions, making him part of the Runeterran community beyond the slums of Zaun.

There are a huge amount of ways that we can have Ekko grow beyond his current isolation. His own desires and needs, or those of other Champions or non-game characters, will be the motivating factors for his story going forward. It's why we changed the world the way we did, we didn't want the IoW to be the answer.

I don't want to spoil anything or pitch anything we don't end up doing, but consider where Ekko is, who else might be around, and what they might want that comes into conflict with Ekko (or even support of him) and you can probably think of half a dozen reasons at least. We want to explore those possibilities.

My reading of the event is also that it nearly destroyed the League. It wasn't like the League had the power to trivially pull Demacia and Noxus apart whenever it wanted, and had just been showing restraint until then. It was an ultimatum: the League used all its power to directly force a brief truce, and compel Demacia and Noxus to confront the reality that, if they continued, the League would be the first casualty. Demacia and Noxus glared at each other, then backed off, each publicly blaming the League for its meddling, while quietly acknowledging that an apocalyptic history had nearly repeated itself.

I find that kind of story so much more exciting than, "and then Demacia and Noxus fought some more." In a literal sense, sure, the League's presence "ended conflict." More accurately, though, I think the League's presence established an entire new dimension of conflict and dramatic tension, and enriched the clash between Demacia and Noxus by showing its larger significance. It made the conflict a lot more interesting.

**EDIT:** I should add, for those less familiar with this discussion, that I don't think this episode indicates, or that the old lore requires, that the League put everything on the line every time two nations start fighting. The League's mandate is not to bring world peace. Sure, there are some idealists who claim that the League can bring true peace one day, but the reality is that the League's mandate is *to prevent another Rune War.* It struggles mightily to achieve even that. It does not have the political capital to be fussy whenever Noxus and Piltover scrap in Shurima, or even whenever Zaun firebombs Ionia. I imagine that the League's general reaction to wars is to move in and lay down some ground rules, limiting the scope of the conflict, and keeping other parties from intervening and escalating it into a world war. So if Noxus invades Ionia, it might say, "alright, fine, Demacia and Zaun, you both stay out of this, and Noxus and Ionia, the fighting stays within this zone." Any Summoner who opined, "then why bother having an army if the League will stop all wars?" would be laughed at pretty heartily in-universe, I think. It's a cute sentiment, the sort associated with people who believe that international law isn't at least as much about power politics as it is legal interpretation.

So why such a dramatic move in Kalamanda? Because you had Runeterra's two superpowers fighting on top of a freaking nexus. That is a recipe for a cataclysmic disaster. This wasn't a border skirmish or a proxy war. Rather, these two very angry, very powerful nations had deployed significant numbers of their own troops (with their own mages backing them up) and readied for a battle in an area intensely charged with magical energy. It would be a mere matter of time before one side started to lose, and those rune spells started looking pretty tempting. I think we can also handwave in something about subtler signs that Demacia and Noxus were tired of skirting the bounds of the laws issued by this League they'd created, and had geared up for another full-scale conflict.

I admit that a good part of this is a "fan hack", and wasn't actually spelled out in the old lore. It's vaguely within the bounds of the old lore. It fits with the spirit of the old lore. To be honest, I think the authors of the old lore were sometimes undecided about how all this stuff worked, and kind of went from issue to issue without a great master plan. Still, I think it's significant to note that a few modest community lore patches solidify the old lore verse into a pretty interesting place.

I really don't see it as a hack at all. It's a perfectly valid interpretation of what happened, and I think labeling it negatively dismisses how useful the League of Legends was for storytelling. It didn't _need_ "hacks" to be interesting and compelling and still provide a framework for plenty of conflict.

(Not to beat the dead horse, but Ionia v. Noxus--come on Riot, you could do stuff like that all the time.)

I know you're tired of hearing this, but... _we're tired of hearing this!_

The idea of characters changing, of seeing their stories evolve over time, is really cool, and I remember thinking that it was a really great potential idea the first time it arose.

This was somewhere around the Lissandra patch, if I remember correctly. So, late April to early May 2013. Two years ago.

If you ask any writer worth their salt, they'll tell you that a story is easier to write with fewer main characters. This is because with each main character, you need an arc, and that arc needs real estate somewhere in the story's greater whole. League of Legends currently has 125 main characters. On average, a new one is added every two months. 

And between today and Lissandra's release, there has been _one event_ that advanced any character lore: the Shurima event. Whose lore did it advance? Sivir's. It also retconned Xerath's origins, and Nasus and Renekton's place in the cosmos. I consider that one step forward and three steps back... four, if you include the addition of yet another main character.

But even setting aside the "steps back," that's ONE character who has had any story advancement. And it was cool, to see Sivir taking a step from cynical mercenary to cynical mercenary with a royal bloodline. But it's not enough. Not nearly enough.

A lot of people are saying that the Narrative team isn't doing anything, and they're wrong - we see that with every new champion release. Ekko in particular has had some fantastic stuff. The Seconds video is great, the comic is just wonderful (look at all the people asking for more of that!), these are great examples of what Narrative is doing.

And yet here's what the Narrative team doesn't seem to want to address:
-There are a huge number of existing champions with story arcs that have not been addressed, and the backlog is not being cleared out as fast as new champions are being added. 
-There is a substantial portion of the playerbase that wants to be served by some sort of literary medium - that is, it's all well and good to get comics and two-minute movies, but people want to _read_ shit, and that leads me to my next point:
-We were told that champion lore would be expanded upon, and that the three-sentence versions we see for some champions on the live client is just a "short version" that would eventually have links to... something bigger, or more stories, or something like that. We were told this roughly around the Shurima event. The Shurima event was in September 2014. We have been waiting for eight months.

I know that that last point is a technical issue, that you need someone to work on the coding side of things for that, but fuck, guys! Fuck! If you have a product or service, it is YOUR JOB to find a way to get it to people. Remember the Azir short story? Remember the Xerath short story? I do, because I was around and active on the forums 8 months ago. What about my one friend who doesn't visit the forums, but is interested in Azir's background beyond his ingame dialog? What about my one friend who just started playing the game, thinks Xerath is all sorts of cool, and wants to learn more? They WANT this stuff. You HAVE this stuff. And yet the pipeline getting this stuff from point A to point B is broken and _no one seems to be doing anything about it._

One thing I notice a lot of amateur writers have in common is that they spend a lot of time thinking about writing and a lot less time doing the actual writing. All these "story hints"? All this "room to grow"? That's _thinking about writing._ That does nothing but piss off the people who actually want to read it. Either do the writing yourself and _put it out there,_ or do what Blizzard does, what Lucasfilm does, what half the creative IPs in the world are doing, and _hire someone to do the writing for you and make mad cash off the results._

You want to know why people are upset? Because all we hear about is how much stuff you want to do and all the ambition the Narrative team has. Ambition means fucking NOTHING unless you do something about it.

So please, from the fans to the Rioters. Either start showing results or hire someone who will.

Here's the thing, we're actually very careful in how often we have characters interact with each other for the exact reason of not wanting to make the world small. A huge danger for world-building is making Champion interactions so common that you feel like they could all be bumping into each other at the line down the local Starbucks.

Yes, they should interact, and when they do, it should be memorable both for its impact and the quality of story. We don't want to throw characters together without being very considered.

Of course, there are exceptions. Garen and Lux might bump into each other in a much more casual way than Ekko and Zilean (though the story of Lux banging on the door because her brother is hogging the bathroom might not be one we focus on).

The focus of Seconds and Chronobreak is to set the stage for Ekko, so it would be a little counterproductive to have another Champion in the limelight in this example.

We do want to have individual stories and some epic encounters between Champions. These kind of stories aren't ideal for throwing other huge personalities in the mix. 

I agree that we need to give that opportunity more often in the process of creating more stories though.
